awd_titl_txt: RUI: Synthesis of Highly Functionalized Heterocyclic Scaffolds
awd_abstract_narration:
In this RUI project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program, Professor Carolyn Anderson of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry at Calvin College creates new methods for the synthesis of complex organic heterocycles.  These are substances which contain nitrogen in a ring. New synthetic routes are primarily based on reactions catalyzed by gold (III). Challenging synthetic targets include indolizine and isoquinoline alkaloids, heterocyclic compounds which possess potential medicinal properties. In addition, this award supports 8-10 week summer visitations to Calvin College by senior graduate students from major research institutions. These visitations provide training for future careers as a PUI faculty member.

This research expands the suite of chiral and achiral methods for preparing highly functionalized trisubstituted indolizine and N-alkyl 2-pyridone structures. This new chemistry makes these species, and their analogues, available to the broader chemical community. Basic knowledge related to mechanistic and asymmetric gold(III) catalysis is an important product of this research. Successful development of these methodologies and targets impacts the synthetic community as well as those involved in the development of organic materials, medicinal leads, and asymmetric transformations. This research provides hands-on laboratory training for undergraduate research collaborators and pre-college students, especially those from historically underrepresented groups. In addition, this award enables senior graduate students, who intend to pursue academic careers at primarily undergraduate institutions, to spend time during a summer as a member of the PI's laboratory. In this role, the visiting graduate students gain essential experience in running a productive undergraduate research group, while being mentored directly by the PI.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Summary. Nitrogen containing heterocycles, such as indolizines, have provoked significant interest in the chemical and biological communities due to their broad medicinal utility. Indolizines bearing either ketones or esters at the C1 position (indolizine numbering) are particularly versatile, having been explored as therapeutic agents for a wide variety of indications, including asthma, cancer, inflammation, and Alzheimer's. As such, the development of simple methods for the generation of highly substituted indolizines, with carbonyl-containing substituents at C1, is an important synthetic goal.

Intellectual Merit. Our previous efforts have demonstrated the utility of simple and readily available 2-alkoxypyridine substrates 1 for the synthesis of the N-alkyl pyridone heterocyclic motifs (Scheme 1). Utilizing this privileged substrate, we have shown during this funding cycle that these same substrates 1 can also be utilized to access highly substituted indolizines, bearing either ketones or esters at C1. This transformation was initial observed as a by-product of earlier work, aimed at the synthesis of another analogue of the novel N-alkyl pyriodone motif 5. Since that initial observation, robust gold(I)-catalyzed methods for the synthesis of indolizines 6 and 7 have been developed, optimized, and reported.

During our efforts to establish a means for the synthesis of ester substituted indolizines 7, we serendipitously discovered and elucidated the structure of novel ketenylidene capped gold(I) trimer 9 (Figure 1). This complex represents only the second ketenylidene capped gold trimer ever reported. Further, the gold-gold molecular distances suggest that the gold atoms are bound to one another, a feature distinct to complex 9.

Broader Impacts. The research funded by this award was conducted by 12 undergraduate researchers, including 4 women, and 2 visiting graduate students (both women). This work has resulted in 3 peer-reviewed publications and 6 presentations at national meetings, despite the award period including 25 months of the COVID-19 pandemic. All of the students funded by this award have graduated. Two are currently pursuing graduate degrees in the chemical sciences (University of North Carolina, University of Pittsburgh), one is in medical school (Wayne State), 6 are employed in the chemical industry, 2 are applying for medical school, and one is working as a nurse.

The visiting graduate student program, funded by this award, allowed for two senior graduate students from research intensive institutions to spend 10 weeks during the summer at Calvin University immersed in the undergraduate research laboratory of the PI. These visiting scholars were directly mentored by the PI, while also overseeing the work of a small group of undergraduates. Both visiting scholars have now completed their PhDs and hold positions as assistant professors at primarily undergraduate institutions (Idaho State University, Virginia Military Institute). The PI has sought to publicize this program and its advantages for training the next generation of faculty at primarily undergraduate institutions through a CUR Chemistry blog post, and its success can be seen through the duplication of this program by several other NSF funded PIs, both at Calvin University and elsewhere, over the past several years.


Last Modified: 08/08/2022
Modified by: Carolyn Anderson
